summary: Coronaviruses are positive-stranded RNA viruses that are frequently associated with enteric or respiratory diseases in humans, livestock and companion animals. a fraction of their proteins are subgroup-specific and the amino-acid sequence of their most conserved proteins may differ by as much as 50%. the FCoV genome (strain FIPV WSU-79/1146) contains 29 125 nucleotides and contains six open reading frames. the first two ORFs encode two large replicase polyproteins, pp1a and pp1ab. proteolytic cleavage of these polyproteins by virus-encoded proteinases predicted to give rise to a total of 16 mature nonstructural proteins. tertiary structures, solved using X-ray or/and NMR analyses, have been reported for a substantial number of nsps from at least one coronavirus, typically SARS-CoV. these structures represent a variety of separate domains, entire proteins and even multiprotein complexes.
